direction.raw_text: Black and white. Street scene. People toing and froing.  A man rattles by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STUDIO, RADIO STATION, WARSAW - DAY WLADYSLAV SZPILMAN plays Chopin's Nocturne in C sharp minor, Posthumous. He's twenty-eight years old, elegant and handsome. In the booth, separated from the studio by a glass screen, an engineer, wearing collar and tie, monitors the broadcast. Behind him, a window to the street with strips of paper taped on it as protection against blast. Without warning, a bomb drops nearby, then another and another. The whole building shudders alarmingly and the window in the booth shatters. The engineer and Szpilman exchange a look as a man enters the booth and talks urgently to the Engineer, then goes. The engineer makes a 'cut-throat' gesture, but Szpilman shakes his head, determined to play on. He plays, then glances at the booth. The engineer has gone, but through the shattered window he sees fires raging. Very near, a loud, terrifying explosion. The reverberations cause plaster to flake and dust to trickle down over his face. And then a bomb explodes even closer. The glass screen separating booth from studio implodes, showering Szpilman with glass. He stops, frozen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pandemonium. Chaos. People rushing in all directions, many carrying files, boxes, papers, shouting, calling. Some of the men in military uniform. The bombing continuous. Szpilman fights his way down the stairs. He has a small cut on his forehead and is dabbing it with his handkerchief. He has a dazed look. Halfway down the stairs, A young woman, DOROTA, tugs at his sleeve:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns, to see an extremely pretty young woman gazing adoringly at him while they're jostled and shoved. His eyes light up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Szpilman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I came specially to meet you today. I love your playing, but what a day to choose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name's Dorota, I'm Jurek's sister. oh! You're bleeding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: pushes in beside them and takes her arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jurek, pulling Dorota, fights his way down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he, too, is carried with the flow into the lobby. Debris everywhere. Szpilman fights to get to the main door, when another bomb explodes, filling the air with dust and debris, obscuring him and everyone else.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, Dorota, you can write him a fan letter later, this isn't the best time, c'mon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Jurek, why have you been hiding her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Szpilman family in panic: coming and going out of rooms, packing clothes and belongings into open suitcases and a trunk in a comfortable, tastefully furnished bourgeois apartment, the living room lined with books, paintings and boasting a boudoir grand, silver platters and candlesticks. The family consist of MOTHER, in a state of great anxiety, FATHER, REGINA, twenty-six, HALINA, twenty-two, and HENRYK, twenty-four, the only one not in movement. He sits by the radio set, ear to the speaker, trying to tune to a station. No bombs now, just the distant sound of artillery fire. Father, holding a silver-framed photograph, crosses to Mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes into his room. She can barely control her tears and hurries into the kitchen just as the front door opens and Szpilman enters, looks round bemused by the activity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother dashes out of the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girls suppress smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father appears in the doorway, beaming, clutching a violin case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The toing and froing continues non-stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts to look. The others continue to bustle and pack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crackles, whistles and static from the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They gather round.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henryk hits the set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Polish national anthem plays. All are still.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What you think, should I take Uncle Szymon's photograph?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take it, don't take it, take what you like. Can't you see I'm worried sick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'll come home, he'll be all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mama, Wladek's home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank God - Wladek! You're wounded.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a little cut, nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been worried sick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told her not to worry. You had your papers on you. If you'd been hit by a bomb, they'd have known where to take you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henryk, don't say things like that, God forbid, God forbid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling through a door) Papa, Wladek's home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did I tell you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking around the room, bemused) What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's it look like we're doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Henryk) They bombed us, we're off the air.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Warsaw's not the only radio station.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pack, darling, get your things, pack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are we going? MOTHER Out of Warsaw.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Out of Warsaw. Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You haven't heard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heard what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Haven't you seen the paper? Where's the paper?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I used it for packing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exasperated) She used it for packing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The government's moved to Lublin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All able-bodied men must leave the city, go across the river and set up a new line of defence, that's what it said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's hardly anybody left in this building, only women, the men have gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what do you think you'll do while you're setting up a new line of defence? Wander round lugging your suitcases?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pack, Wladek, there's no time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going anywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good! I'm not going anywhere either!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be ridiculous, we've got to keep together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, no, I'm staying put. If I'm going to die, I prefer to die at home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God forbid!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sssh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ssh! I've got something, listen...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... an important announcement. News has just been received through the BBC that Great Britain, having had no reply... (static) ...and therefore has declared war on Nazi Germany... (a collective gasp) ... next few hours... awaiting latest news...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... but France is expected to make a similar announcement... (static) ... Poland is no longer alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Father pours liqueur into glasses. The family are seated around the dining table, having just finished a meal. The table groans with the remains of the dinner. Szpilman has a plaster over his cut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The glasses are handed round.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all clink glasses and drink.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (lighting up a cigarette) Mama, that was a great dinner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It certainly was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When there's something to celebrate, you've got to make an effort.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here's to Great Britain and France.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told you. Didn't I tell you? All will be well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A column of German Soldiers, led by an officer on horseback, march into view. On the sidewalk of the street, with its buildings in ruins, smoke still rising, stand onlookers, including Szpilman and Henryk, and a little behind them, Father, craning to see. They watch, expressionless, as the Germans march past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Regina is opening and closing the window, examining the frame with her fingers. Halina is on a box, removing and replacing books. Mother sits at one end of the table, polishing a man's watch and chain. At the other end, Father sits counting a small stack of notes and coins. Henryk is deep in thought and Szpilman is fiddling with his father's violin. The apartment has less furniture now and the silver has gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All look at the table: it's covered in stains and the veneer is coming away at one end. A table like this? He pokes his finger under the veneer. It snaps, revealing bare wood beneath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all talk at once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A brief silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start to hide the things.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (finishing the counting) Five thousand and three.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, five thousand and three zlotys, that's all we've got left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's three thousand and three zlotys too much, (reading from newspaper) 'Re: Further restrictions regarding liquid assets: Jews will be allowed to keep a maximum of two thousand zlotys in their homes.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are we supposed to do with the rest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Deposit it in a bank. Blocked account.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Banks? Who'd be stupid enough to deposit money in a German bank?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We could hide the money here in the window frame.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, no. I'll tell you what we'll do. We'll use tried and tested methods. You know what we did in the last war? We made a hole in the table leg and we hid the money in there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And suppose they take the table away?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What d'you mean, take the table away?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Germans go into Jewish homes and they just take what they want, furniture, valuables, anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Idiot! What would they want with a table?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What on earth are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a good place under the cupboard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no. Listen, I've been thinking -- SZPILMAN That makes a change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what we do? We use psychology.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We use what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We leave the money and the watch on the table. And we cover it like this. (covers it with the newspaper) In full view. The Germans will search high and low, I promise you, they'll never notice it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course they'll notice it. But look-- (lifts the violin fingerboard.) This is a good place for something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A good place for what? (to the others') He's insane!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just shut up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (overlapping) My violin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quiet! Quiet! Order, please, order!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's a lawyer, she likes order.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, just listen. Let's come to an agreement. We jam the money in the window frame. The watch we hide under the cupboard. And the chain we put in the violin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will I still be able to play?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's find out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman is on the public telephone, waiting for someone to answer his call. Then:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jurek? Wladek Szpilman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (filtered) Wladek! How are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, we're fine, thank you, and you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (filtered) Fine, we're fine in the circumstances. But I can guess what you've called about. There's nothing we can do; they won't reopen the station--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to interrupt) Yes, I know, but Jurek, Jurek...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (filtered) ...not even music, nothing, no radios for the Poles. But I'm sure you'll find work, Wladek, a pianist like you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe, maybe not, but, Jurek, don't be offended, I didn't call to discuss my future career.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman and Dorota stroll along a tree-lined street with bombed-out buildings and rubble. She flicks admiring, almost loving glances at him as they walk and talk. And he is smiling, touched by her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She begins to laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They become almost helpless, holding on to each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amidst their laughter, he takes her hand and kisses it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I nagged Jurek for weeks and weeks. And at last he gave in and said, 'All right, come with me tomorrow,' and so I came and they bombed the station.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know something? Meeting you like that was absolutely wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes! (he looks at her, smiles) It was...it was unforgettable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've always loved your playing, Mr. Szpilman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wladek, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one plays Chopin like you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could accompany you, me on the piano, you on the cello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Mr Szpilman, you're quite... quite wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wladek, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The family are gathered around the table, listening to Father reading from the newspaper. The apartment has even less furniture now. The paintings are gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence, each locked in their own thoughts.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) 'Re: emblems for Jews in the Warsaw District. I hereby order that all Jews in the Warsaw District will wear visible emblems when out of doors. This decree will come into force on the 1st December 1939 and applies to all Jews over twelve years of age. The emblem will be worn on the right sleeve and will represent a blue Star of David on a white background. The background must be sufficiently large for the Star to measure eight centimetres from point to point. The width of the arms of the Star (reading) must be one centimetre. Jews who do not respect this decree will be severely punished. Governor of Warsaw District, Dr. Fischer.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't wear it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: won't wear it. I'm not going to be branded.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grabbing the newspaper) Let me see this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doesn't it say we have to provide these armbands ourselves? Where will we get them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're not going to get them. We're not going to wear them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Father, wearing the Star of David armband, walks slowly along, carrying a string bag containing potatoes and carrots, his eyes fixed on the pavement as if his thoughts are a million miles away. He passes two GERMAN OFFICERS. They stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father stops, turns fearfully and approaches the Germans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I German Officer cracks him hard across the face, catching his ear. Father reels, collects himself as best he can and starts to shuffle on -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father steps off the pavement and walks in the gutter. The German turn and go. Father walks on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (a harsh shout) You!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you bow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (removing his hat) I'm sorry I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling after him) You are forbidden to walk on the pavement. Walk in the gutter!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman composing at the piano. He plays, makes adjustments with a pencil to the manuscript, plays again. The flat is almost bare. Halina, enters with a newspaper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands him the paper. He looks at it. His expression darkens.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Have you seen this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritated) What, I'm working, what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : the newspaper. A map of the proposed Jewish area: two distinct districts, one large, one smaller.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's where they're going to put us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What d'you mean, put us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : She looks over his shoulder and reads. As she does so, the door of Henryk's room opens and he stands leaning in the doorway, watching, as if amused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman gazes at the map, horrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs but they're disturbed by a sound from another room, the sound of crying. They look at each other puzzled, then Halina opens a door and looks in. Szpilman and Henryk join her. BEDROOM: Father is asleep but Mother is sitting on the bed, holding a purse, crying. Halina sits beside her, puts an arm round her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother opens the purse to reveal a crumpled note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She weeps. Halina tries to comfort her. Szpilman and Henryk watch.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: 'By order of the Governor of the Warsaw District, Dr. Fischer, concerning the establishment of the Jewish District in Warsaw. There will be created a Jewish District in which all Jews living in Warsaw or moving to Warsaw will have to reside."  And look here: 'Jews living outside of the prescribed area will have to move to the Jewish district by 31st of October 1940.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But...they won't get all of us... we'll...it's too small...there's four hundred thousand of us in Warsaw!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Three hundred and sixty thousand, so it'll be easy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mama, what is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty zlotys. That's all we've got left. What can I buy with twenty zlotys? (breaking down) I'm sick of cooking potatoes, potatoes, potatoes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hands on the piano keyboard. Podgy, hairy hands with dirty nails. They play an octave, harsh, toneless, with straight fingers. The hands belong to Mr Lipa, a dealer, early fifties. He sits at the piano, now examining the lacquer. Regina stands in the bow, watching him. Henryk is at the table, also watching intently. Szpilman sits apart, aloof, his back to the piano and to Mr Lipa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henryk suddenly makes a lunge for him, grabs hold of him, a rough struggle takes place and during it Mother and Father appear at their bedroom door to watch, appalled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Regina tries physically to restrain him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henryk subsides, glowering at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's the price. That's what I'm offering. And my advice is to accept. You won't get more from anyone else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But...but it's a Steinway, Mr Lipa...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two thousand. My advice is to take it. What you going to do when you're hungry? Eat the piano?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get out! You're a thieving bastard, we don't want your money, get out! We'd rather give it away! Get out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (overlapping, warding off Henryk) Hey! Hey! What's the matter with you? Haven't you eaten today, what you suffering from? Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (overlapping) Henryk, stop it, leave him alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (recovering, catching his breath, overlapping) You people are crazy! I'm doing you a favour, two thousand, and I'm paying for the removal, I'm not even charging for the removal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You haven't eaten today, you're crazy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning to them, severe) Take it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A great column of Jews of all ages make their way towards the area that will become the ghetto. On foot, on bicycles, on horse-drawn platforms, some pushing prams loaded with belongings. A great moving mass of humanity. They're watched on either side of the street by Poles. On a horse-drawn platform, the Szpilmans with their belongings.  All wear armbands. Szpilman, Halina and Henryk walk beside the platform with Mother, Father and Regina seated on it. Szpilman catches sight of someone among the onlookers, smiles and pushes through the crowd to Dorota, close to tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles and runs to catch up with his family. He looks back, but Dorota is lost to sight and the procession continues on its way.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dorota!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't want to come, I didn't want to see all this, but I couldn't stop myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, no, not really, they arrested my cousin, but Jurek says they'll let him out. (stops, tears in her eyes.) This is disgraceful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, it won't last long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I said, it's so - it's too absurd!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see you...soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Two rooms on the third floor: a living room and a kitchen. The Szpilmans are unpacking their belongings in silence. Father pauses for a moment to take stock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all go to the window and look out. Their POV - the street. Further along, men are building a wall across the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: To tell you the truth, I thought it would be worse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How will we sleep?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll sleep with the girls in the kitchen. You, Henrykc and Papa in here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (at a window) Look! Come and look!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : THE WALL. THE WALL. THE WALL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winter. Cold, freezing day. Slush underfoot. Great activity. People selling shoes, clothes, carpets, curtains, food. A woman offers cakes under a barbed-wire cover. Noise, bustle, restless wing and froing. Among the traders, Henryk, slightly shabbier now, and at his feet a basket with books. He holds a couple of volumes in his hands, trying to interest passers-by. Szpilman, also a little shabbier, wends his way through the setters and buyers, the beggars, the passers-by, and reaches Henryk. Henryk drops the two volumes into the basket, takes a handle one side of the basket, Szpilman the other. They set off. As they walk, carrying the basket between them, passing beggars and children asking for food:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, a WOMAN appears in front of them, barring their way. She's brightly rouged with thickly painted eyebrows, dressed in an old green velvet curtain with an unsteady mauve ostrich feather rising from her straw hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shake their heads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She wanders on. Szpilman and Henryk, too, continue on their way. And as they go:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You sell anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just one. Dostoevsky. The Idiot. Three zlotys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's better than yesterday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Three lousy zlotys. And there are people here making millions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't know, believe me. They bribe the guards. The guards turn a blind eye. They're bringing in cartloads, food, tobacco, liquor, French cosmetics, and the poor are dying all around them and they don't give a damn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, but have you by any chance seen my husband Izaak Szerman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A tall handsome man with a little grey beard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No? (she is near to tears, then smiles artificially.) Oh, do forgive me. (as she goes) Goodbye, sleep well, if you see him, please do write, Izaak Szerman's his name...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes I wish I could go mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A stream of cars and trams. Jewish policemen and German soldiers much in evidence. Szpilman and Henryk join a large crowd of Jews waiting at a barrier to cross the intersection. The crowd is agitated, impatient for a policeman to stop the traffic and let them through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: next to Szpilman and Henryk is becoming more and more distraught, shifting his weight from foot to foot, taking off and putting on his hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meanwhile, a street band begins to play a waltz. Jewish policemen and German soldiers are clearing a space, shoving Jews out of the way, including Szpilman, Henryk and the nervous man. Other soldiers are clearing a space. Two GERMAN SOLDIERS pull out of the crowd a tall woman and a short man and haul them into the cleared space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The couple dance to the street band's waltz. At intervals, German soldiers select even more unlikely couples: a fat woman with a painfully thin man, a young boy with an elderly woman, two men, and two cripples. The German soldiers are, to various degrees, amused. One of them is almost hysterical with laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The couples dance as fast as they can. A soldier kicks one of the cripples who can't go on any more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then a whistle blows, a policeman stops the traffic, the barrier swings open and people swarm across in both directions.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is totally insane; why do we have to have a gentile street running through our area? Can't they go around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry about it, they're about to build a bridge, haven't you heard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A bridge, a schmidge, and the Germans claim to be intelligent. You know what I think?  I think they're totally stupid. I've got a family to feed and I spend half my time here waiting for them to let us through.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dance!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Faster! Go on, faster! Dance!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dance! Dance!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman and Henryk enter and stop. Uneasy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seated at the table with Mother and Father is a uniformed young man, YITZCHAK HELLER, unusual appearance, a man with red hair and a Hitler moustache. Heller remains seated, just nods at the brothers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henryk and Szpilman sit. They eye Heller suspiciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Awkward silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs dry. Another awkward silence. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. Heller rises angrily.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good, they're here. Yitzchak Heller's been waiting for you, Henryk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's this about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sit down, have tea, I'll start lunch when the girls get back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, what are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He brought cakes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His father's back in the jewellery business and doing well, isn't that so, Yitzchak? Amazing. Jewellery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're recruiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's recruiting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be clever with me, Henryk. I've come here as a friend. They're bringing Jews in from all over the country. Soon there'll be half a million people in the ghetto. We need more Jewish police...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastic) Oh? More Jewish police? You mean you want me to wear a cap like yours, beat up Jews with my truncheon and catch the Gestapo spirit. I see!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eyes narrowed, dangerous) Someone's got to do it, Henryk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But why me? I thought you only recruited boys with rich fathers. Look at my father, look at us, I mean...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting, flaring) Yes, I'm looking at you and that's why I'm here. Your whole family can have a better life. You want to go on struggling for survival, selling books on the street?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a smile) Yes, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Szpilman) I'm doing you people a favour. And what about you, Wladek? You're a great pianist. And we've got an excellent police jazz band. They'd welcome you with open arms. Join us. You've got no work...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. But I've got work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On a platform, Szpilman plays at a piano, but he can hardly be heard above the noise of chatter and laughter. The large cafe is crowded, hot and smoke-filled. Well-heeled customers, pimps, whores, businessmen sit at little tables, eating, talking, laughing, almost drowning the piano music. Some dance. A couple of tables back from the piano, a customer is doing business with a friend. The customer has a small stack of coins, some of them twenty-dollar gold pieces. He folds back the tablecloth to reveal a marble surface beneath. He drops a coin on the marble and listens but the noise is too loud. He sees the cafe owner, BENEK, fiftyish, and makes gestures, pointing at Szpilman. Benek pushes his way through to Szpilman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Benek points to the customer, who makes an imploring gesture to Szpilman. Szpilman stops playing. The friend watches the customer intently as he drops the coins one by one onto the marble. He drops them, puts his ear close and listens.  Two or three he discards, but he smiles when coins make a pure tone, and he keeps them. Szpilman exchanges looks with a pretty whore, who makes eyes at him. Satisfied, the customer beams, nods his thanks to Szpilman, who resumes his piano playing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering into Szpilman's ear) I'm sorry, Mr Wladek, he wants you to stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing to play) Who wants me to stop?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman walking. He passes emaciated children and beggars. He steps over the corpses lying on the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wall runs the length of the street, dividing it in half and narrowing it. Buildings on one side, the wall on the other. Szpilman walks along. A piercing whistle from the Aryan side.  Szpilman stops. Two women appear from a doorway, approach the wall and look up.  Two or three packages come flying over from the Aryan side. The women grab them and disappear. Szpilman walks on and sees a child appear through a hole at ground level. The child wriggles through then turns, pulls a package after him and runs. Szpilman walks on, hears a noise, looks back to see a SECOND CHILD trying to wriggle through the same hole. But he's stuck. Angry German voices from the Aryan side. 2ND CHILD Help me! help me! Szpilman goes to him, pulls him with all his might but the boy is jammed in the hole. From the other side of the wall, the sound of an angry German voice and of a boot stamping violently on the boy. The boy screams in agony. Szpilman continues to try to pull the boy through. The sound of the German voice swearing and the dull, crunching noise made by the boot smashing into the boy continues, and with every thud the boy screams in terrible pain. Szpilman struggles to help the boy whose screams are becoming weaker yet increasingly desperate. Szpilman pulls his arms and finally manages to get him through. The boy lies moaning. Szpilman takes the boy's face in his hands, tries to comfort him, revive him, but the boy has stopped moaning. His head lolls and his jaw sags. He is dead. Szpilman stands quickly and hurries away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman approaches the house through a shabby yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The noise of a mimeograph machine. A huge, CHEERFUL MAN with a perpetual cigarette in his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs and coughs, starts looking through papers. His room is piled from floor to ceiling with old papers and stuff. Dark, shabby, run-down. One of his sons, SYMCHE, is operating the mimeograph machine. The other, DOLEK, is sorting the sheets as they come off the roller.  MRS. ZYSKIND, holding a toddler, is cooking at a small stove.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I always say look on the bright side. You're in the small ghetto, intellectuals, professional people, you're better off than us. Here, in the large ghetto, it's a cesspool. But you, you're living in Monte Carlo. You could say you're privileged and that, of course, goes against my principles. Nevertheless...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: finds what he's been looking for, a newspaper made up of a few sheets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He beams. Szpilman leans over, takes a sheet from the mimeograph.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He loves this, laughs, coughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A distinctive knock on the door. Szpilman tenses but Jehuda beams. To one of his boys: Symche - The boy opens the door to admit a short, neat man, MAJOREK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops, seeing Szpilman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jehuda loves this too, but his laugh makes him cough appallingly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, here. Today's news from the other side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're amazing, Jehuda.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm a socialist. I have brothers everywhere. They bring me news and food. We care about our fellow human beings. Workers of the world unite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, what's the news?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (scanning the paper) The Germans are advancing on Kharkhov.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know why I come here every evening, it's always such bad news.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bad news, you crazy? You have no world view, Wladek, that's your trouble. The news couldn't be better. The moment Hitler invaded Russia, I knew we'd be all right. Remember Napoleon. Same business. The Germans will freeze to death, please God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jehuda, give me something to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're an artist, Wladek, you keep people's spirits up. You do enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I want to help, I want to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're too well known, Wladek. And you know what? You musicians don't make good conspirators. You're too...too musical.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are notices going up. The city's to be cleansed of undesirables.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are always notices going up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Symche, Dolek, Mrs Zyskind, Jehuda. Working hard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majorek, this is the greatest pianist in Poland, maybe in the whole world. Wladyslaw Szpilman. Meet Majorek.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes Szpilman's hand) I know your name. I've never heard you play.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majorek used to be in the army. Brilliant man. He's got a mind like a searchlight. The only thing I've got against him is he's not a socialist. (he looks out of the window.) You'd better go now, Wladek. It's nearly curfew. (he hands over pamphlets to Majorek.) You see these, Wladek?  You know how many copies we print of our newspaper?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Five hundred. You know how many people on average read one copy? Twenty.  That makes ten thousand readers. These will start the uprising. Majorek hides them in his underpants. And leaves them in toilets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Toilets?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As many toilets as I can find. Germans never go into Jewish toilets. They're too clean for them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Summer. The windows are open and the sounds of the ghetto can be heard in the background. The family sit round the small table as Mother comes with a saucepan of soup and starts to serve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs. No one else does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others look at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, there's a roar of engines and a screech of brakes. Slamming of doors. The family rush to the windows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And, please, tonight, for once, I don't want anything bad talked about. Let's enjoy our meal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, then I'll tell you something funny. You know who I mean by Dr. Raszeja.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The surgeon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The surgeon. Well, for some reason, don't ask me why, the Germans allowed him into the ghetto to perform an operation...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On a Jew? They allowed a Pole to come in to operate on a Jew?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He got a pass, that's all I know. Anyway, he puts the patient to sleep and starts the operation. He'd just made the first incision when the SS burst in, shoot the patient lying on the table, and then shoot Dr. Raszeja and everybody else who was there. Isn't that a laugh? The patient didn't feel a thing, he was anaesthetised -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henryk, I said nothing bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter with you all? Have you lost your sense of humour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not funny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you know what's funny? You're funny with that ridiculous tie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you talking about, my tie? What's my tie got to do with anything? I need the tie for my work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boys, boys...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your work, yes, playing the piano for all the parasites in the ghetto, they don't give a damn about people's sufferings, they don't even notice what's going on around them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I blame the Americans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For what? For my tie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: American Jews, and there's lots of them, what have they done for us? What do they think they're doing? People here are dying, haven't got a bite to eat. The Jewish bankers over there should be persuading America to declare war on Germany!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gestapo vehicle has entered the street and screeched to a halt.  Helmeted, jackbooted SS MEN, led by an NCO, pour out of the vehicle. The Szpilmans gather at their open window to watch. Regina turns off the lights before joining them. They are all terrified. Their half-eaten meal still on the table behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - from Szpilman apartment: the building opposite. The SS men pouring into the building opposite. Sound of the jackboots on stairs. Lights go on floor by floor. In an apartment directly opposite, a businessman, his wife, three young people and an old man in a wheelchair sit at their dining table. The SS men burst in, machine pistols at the ready. The family is frozen with horror, remain seated. The NCO scans their faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The family rise to their feet fast, except for the old man in the wheelchair. The NCO bears down on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man in the wheelchair grips the arms of the chair and tries desperately to stand. But he can't. Without warning, the SS men seize the chair with the old man in it, carry him out on to the balcony. THE SZPILMANS: Mother SCREAMS, Father shrinks back, Halina comforts him and Regina comforts Mother. Szpilman's and Henryk 's POV - the apartment opposite: The SS men throw the old man in his wheelchair over the balcony. He seems to hang in the air for a second then drops out of the chair and out of sight. But there's a terrible thud as his body hits the pavement and a clatter as the wheelchair follows him. THE SZPILMANS: Mother sobbing. The others, still horrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then sound of shots, slamming doors, screams, shouts. Szpilman and Henryk hurry to another window so that they can see what's going on. Their POV from second window building opposite and street:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in a towering rage) Stand up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stand up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly, to Mother) Be quiet, Mama, for God's sake, be quiet!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Men herding a couple of dozen prisoners from the building opposite. People watching from the windows but trying not to be seen. The headlights of the SS vehicle are switched on and the SS Men are forcing their prisoners to stand in the beam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The prisoners start to run. The SS men open fire with a machine gun mounted on the vehicle. People in the building opposite begin to SCREAM. The prisoners are being shot down. They are lifted into the air by the bullets, turn somersaults, fall dead. One man escapes by running back in the opposite direction, out of the beam of light and is lost to sight for a moment. The escaping man, a silhouette, out of the light, runs with all his strength, putting distance between himself and the SS. He starts to scale a wall. He looks as though he's getting away. But there's a floodlight on the SS vehicle. It flares into light, swivels and finds the man. A volley of shots. The man drops from the wall, dead. The SS men get into the vehicle and speed off, driving over the dead bodies. THE SZPILMANS: Szpilman and Henryk stare at the scene, silent, shocked. The only sounds, the weeping of the people opposite and, nearer, Mother crying softly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Run!  Run!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman, as if in another world, playing the piano. The cafe is full of customers but the atmosphere is much more subdued than previously, the mood is sombre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A doorman with a cudgel beats away the beggars from the door as Halina, distraught and out of breath, runs to the cafe entrance. The doorman lets her in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman snaps out of his reverie, seeing, across the heads of the customers, Halina, in a state of great anxiety, beckoning urgently. Szpilman quickly brings the piece to a close, stands, steps off the platform, threads his way through to Halina. She's shivering, almost unable to speak.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost incoherent) Oh my God, it's terrible, you've got to do something, oh my God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking her) Calm down, what, what is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're hunting people on the streets. They've picked up Henryk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman running. Streets crowded. Corpses. Szpilman, sweating, dodges and sidesteps. Then, suddenly, a woman bars his way. She's the Feather Woman, brightly rouged, with her thickly painted eyebrows, the unsteady mauve ostrich feather rising from her straw hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tries to dodge past but she grabs his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman manages to free himself and runs on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, but have you seen my husband Izaak Szerman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's tall, he's handsome. He has a little grey beard. If you see him, please do write, Izaak Szerman's his name, don't forget.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A mob of men in front of the building being herded this way and that by Jewish policemen. More and more captive men are brought in by the German Schutzpolizei (Shupos). The mob constantly swelling. Szpilman reaches the back of the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman scans the mob. The Jewish policemen using batons and whips to herd the men. No sign of Henryk. Szpilman becomes alert. He's seen someone he recognises. Heller, with his red hair and Hitler moustache, wielding a baton, driving men into the building. With difficulty, Szpilman pushes his way through the mob and gets nearer to Heller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heller doesn't hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heller glances round.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heller shoves someone aside so that Szpilman can approach, but he continues to beat and manhandle people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heller just glares at Szpilman and then moves away. Szpilman stands, jostled by the crowd, uncertain, forlorn.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to an elderly man nearest him) What's happening?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They've got my grandson in there. They pick 'em up, they take 'em away. What do they do to them? I've stopped believing in God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (yelling) Yitzchak!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yitzchak!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, please! Wladek Szpilman!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henryk's in there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't seen him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Believe me, they've picked him up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tough luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you help?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, you need me now, yes, now you need me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you help us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It costs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've no money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then there's nothing I can do. He should've joined us when I gave him the chance..
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yitzchak, they told me you had influence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who told you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People I know. They said you're an important man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ALLEY AND LABOUR BUREAU, LATER - MID-AFTERNOON Szpilman, keeping to the shadows of the alleyway, watches the front of the building. Comings and goings. German Soldiers in evidence. The mob is smaller now. Szpilman waits and watches, and then a POOR WOMAN passes, carrying a can wrapped in newspaper followed by a RAGGED OLD MAN, dragging himself along. He's shivering with cold, his shoes with holes show his purple feet. The ragged old man suddenly lunges forward and tries to grab the can from the poor woman. They struggle desperately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The can falls to the pavement and thick, steaming soup pours into the dirty street. Szpilman watches, rooted to the spot. The ragged old man stares at the can, lets out a groan, more like a whimper, and throws himself full length in the slush, licking the soup up from the pavement. The poor woman starts to howl, kicking the old man and tearing at her hair in despair. Then:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (screaming) A snatcher! Help me, a snatcher!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boys, keep your peckers up! And girls, keep your legs crossed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a ragged, dishevelled little man, Chaplinesque, waving a stick, hopping and jumping, approaches the Germans outside the bureau.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He approaches a couple of Shupos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He waves his stick at them. They laugh. One of them bows low.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Almost in tears with laughter, they give him a cigarette and he goes on his way. Szpilman almost smiles, then looks again at the building. He waits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't let 'em get you down -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bandits! Crooks!  Thieves!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good day, Herr Rubinstein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If that means good day, I'm your man, you gangsters, robbers, pirates!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tapping his head) Mad!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ich bin meshuge, you bandit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ALLEY AND LABOUR BUREAU, LATER - DUSK Sun just setting. From the shelter of the alleyway, Szpilman continues to watch the entrance of the bureau. No mob any more, but people come and go - jewish policemen, shupos, a few jews. Almost continuous sounds of distant shots and screams. Then, Heller appears at the entrance, looks this way and that and goes back inside the building. Szpilman alert. Again Heller appears in the entrance. He beckons someone inside. Henryk shuffles out. Heller shoves him into the street. Henryk stumbles, falls. Szpilman runs to him, helps him to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start to walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk on. EXT. CHLODNA STREET BRIDGE - DUSK A wooden bridge has been constructed, linking the small ghetto to the large ghetto. Few people about, mostly beggars and children. Szpilman and Henryk climb the stairs of the bridge, but as they reach the bridge itself Henryk stumbles, sinks to his knees. Szpilman gets hold of him, tries to help him stand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (immediately on the attack, furious) You go to Heller, did I ask you to talk to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're out, aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you beg, did you grovel to that piece of shit, that cockroach?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't grovel, I asked him to help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you pay him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pay him? With what? With what could I pay him? Every zloty I earn we spend on food!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can look after myself!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They were taking you away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's nothing to do with you. It's me they wanted, not you. Why do you interfere in other people's business?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're mad, that's your trouble, you're mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's also my business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter? Are you sick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hungry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman supports Henryk, helps him towards the back of the cafe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henryk, finishing a bowl of soup and a piece of bread, sits at a worktop with Szpilman and Benek. The kitchen is small and busy with cooks, waiters, washers-up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's that mean, no employment certificate?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have to have an employment certificate to work for one of the German firms in the ghetto, otherwise...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Otherwise what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll be deported.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So the rumours were true...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're going to resettle us. Send us to labour camps. In the east. And they're closing the small ghetto.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A dense crowd of people crossing the bridge in both directions. Szpilman, shabby and unshaven, hurries along and meets Jehuda Zyskind coming towards him, accompanied by the small man, Majorek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're buffeted by the crowd. In the street below them, cars, trams, pedestrians and German guards.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wladek!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you'd be off on tour, playing London, Paris, New York?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to smile) Not this week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to say you look terrible. What's the trouble?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've heard the rumours they're going to resettle us in the East?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dismissing him) Rumours, rumours, you take it all too much to heart, Wladek.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been trying to get a certificate of employment for my father. I've managed to get certificates for me and the rest of the family but I need one more for my father. I've been trying all the firms, the shops...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you come to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't know you were in the certificate business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not, but Majorek is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Majorek) Can you help? I've no money...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, don't insult us. (to Majorek) Can you do something for him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be at the Schultz Workshop, tomorrow, four o'clock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see what a wonderful piece of luck you've had today? That's die historical imperative in action and that's why I always say, look on...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (joining with him) ...the bright side, yes, I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The name 'Samuel Szpilman' being written on a certificate. The clatter of sewing machines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a fat, sweaty German is filling out the form at his desk. Majorek beside him, standing, chatting to him and having a quiet laugh. In the doorway, Szpilman and Father. The small office is on an upper level with a window looking down on the factory floor where Jewish men and women are hard at work on sewing machines making the terrible clatter. Schultz stamps the certificate, hands it to Majorek, who gives it to Father.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (doffing his hat) Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beaming, German accent) My pleasure. It won't help you anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A great mass of agitated people crossing only one way: from the small ghetto to the large ghetto, carrying their belongings. A German film crew records the scene. The Szpilmans among the crowd, lugging suitcases and bundles, Henryk with a few books, Father carrying his violin case. They struggle across the bridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A truck backing up. The tail-gate is opened to reveal a huge load of furniture, linen, clothing, mirrors, carpets, bedclothes. Three Jews inside the van start to unload the stuff, dumping it in the yard. Other Jews stand ready to start sorting the load, among them the Szpilman family. Shupos and Jewish policemen supervise. Each has their allotted task: Szpilman and Henryk sort out carpets, Father mirrors, Regina linen, Halina and Mother, clothing. The sounds of trains not far off. They carry the stuff into the warehouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman and the others bring their piles of things into the warehouse, which is crammed with similar objects, an Aladdin's cave. The activity continuous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: semi-darkness. A large room with an improvised partition of blankets to separate the men from the women. Three-tiered bunks. On the men's side, Father is on the upper bunk, Henryk on the lower. Szpilman, stripping down to his underwear, is preparing to climb into the middle bunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman nods, climbs into his bunk, settles down. Somewhere near, the sound of a train. Then a volley of shots, German voices shouting. Szpilman slips off his bunk, hurries to the door, opens it and comes face to face with a German NCO and soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The NCO cracks Szpilman across the face, turns and goes. Szpilman retreats into the room, his nose bleeding. The women are watching from behind the blankets, but Mother hurries towards Szpilman. She wipes his nose. Shots, shouts, a scream.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: At least we've got work in the ghetto. At least we're still together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Out! Assemble in the yard!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're employed here, we've got certificates -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Still quite dark. The Szpilmans and about twenty others lined up under lights shining on them from a couple of German vehicles. The NCO goes along the line, making a selection, using his pistol to prod people into moving. When he gets to the Szpilmans he selects Henryk and Halina. Then, he turns to those who are left:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The NCO turns his pistol on the young woman and shoots her through the head. He marches off while she lies on the ground with blood spurting out of her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The rest of you get dressed then report back here. Bring your belongings. Fifteen kilos only.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you taking us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The partition has been pulled aside. People, including the Szpilmans, are dressing or dressed, packing up their belongings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds of shots, screams, shouts, a piercing whistle.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, I did my best, I thought the certificates would save us all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it, Wladek.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's just hope that Henryk and Halina will be better off -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hot, fine summer's day. Jews, among them Szpilman, Mother, Regina and father, clutching their meagre belongings, walk towards wooden gates and come to a halt. Jewish policemen approach and order the people about, pushing and shoving them into line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: #1 You're going to work. You'll be much better off than in this stinking ghetto. The gates are The gates are opened. JEWISH POLICEMAN #2 Move! They shuffle forward.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to a Jewish policeman) Where will we be going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman, Mother, Regina and Father, with others, enter through one of the gates, which closes on them. They pause for a moment to take in their new surroundings. The Szpilmans and their POV: Their first sight of the large rectangle, walled on two sides and overlooked by buildings. Several hundred people. People walk up and down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he stops again, and so do the others. Something they see causes them to stand stock still, expressionless.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's sit over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : An unoccupied space at the edge of the compound where bloated, decaying bodies lie near to a wall. The wall itself is spattered with blood. Large flies walk over the dead. Nobody goes near.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Szpilman turns away and leads the others to another space. Later: Glaring sun. The Szpilmans have settled down on the kerb of a pavement and are waiting. Szpilman stands, observing the scene. Mother sits on a bundle of things, staring vacantly, her hair hanging down in strands. Regina, beside her, has her hands over her face and is weeping, the tears running through her fingers. Father walks nervously up and down, hands behind his back, four steps one way, four steps back. Near them, a YOUNG WOMAN begins to wail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A young man, beside her, whispers to her, but she does not seem to take in what he's saying. Her cries continue at intervals. THE YOUNG WOMAN Why did I do it? Why did I do it? The sound of trucks. Everyone looks towards the gates. More Jews are being unloaded from trucks and are marched through the gates. Mothers, children, old people, begging, most of them holding papers. Pandemonium. Later: The sun high, blazing. Szpilman is wandering around, occasionally greeting people. The place is crowded now, packed. Trucks bring more and more Jews at intervals. Old people lying down, exhausted, impossible to tell whether some of them are alive or dead. Women carrying dehydrated children drag themselves from group to group. One WOMAN approaches Szpilman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman shakes his head sadly. The woman with child wanders off to another group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman turns to see a man, DR. EHRLICH, haranguing Father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman goes to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another man, Grun, joins in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A loud cry from Mother. Szpilman and Father spin round.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Near the gates, among a large bunch of new arrivals, Henryk and Halina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Regina and Szpilman also call and wave. Henryk and Halina struggle through to them. Halina falls into Mother's arms and they hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother comforts her. And so does Regina. Father smiles sadly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman stands and stares at her. Later: The sun lower but the heat still intense. The place is now packed to suffocation. People calling out names, trying to find each other. The wailing of women and the cries of children. A cordon of Jewish policemen and SS guards are, almost surreptitiously, ringing the compound. The Szpilmans sit in the same place, with Henryk sitting a little apart and now reading a small book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grun leans across to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Halina looks at him in disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later: Szpilman and Henryk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman takes the book and reads the title page: THE MERCHANT OF VENICE BY WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later: The Szpilmans seated on the kerb. Their attention is caught by a BOY who has a box of sweets on a string round his neck. And he's setting the sweets, pocketing money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father calls to the Sweet Boy and beckons him over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They search their pockets and handbags, hand over to Father what change they can find. He, in turn, hands the money to the Sweet Boy, who hands over one caramel and goes on his way. Father holds the caramel between thumb and forefinger and examines it carefully. Then, carefully takes out his penknife and with great care divides the caramel into six pans. He hands a part to each of the family. They all exchange a look, an acknowledgement of each other, almost like a toast, and then they chew, slowly, deliberately. The whistle of a locomotive. Sound of trucks rattling over the rails. At once, a sound of great agitation from the Jews in the compound.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why did I do it? Why did I do it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's dying, don't you have a drop of water? My child's dying of thirst, he's dying, he's dying, I beg you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm telling you, it's a disgrace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can hear you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . EHRLICH (overlapping) We're letting them take us to our death like sheep to the slaughter!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Ehrlich, not so loud!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . EHRLICH Why don't we attack them? There's half a million of us, we could break out of the ghetto. At least we could die honourably, not as a stain on the face of history!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why you so sure they're sending us to our death?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . EHRLICH I'm not sure. You know why I'm not sure? Because they didn't tell me. But I'm telling you they plan to wipe us all out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Ehrlich, what do you want me to do? You want me to fight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To fight you need organisation, plans, guns!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's right. What d'you think I can do? Fight them with my violin bow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Germans would never squander a huge labour force like this. They're sending us to a labour camp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . EHRLICH Oh, sure. Look at that cripple, look at those old people, the children, they're going to work? Look at Mr Szpilman here, he's going to carry iron girders on his back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henryk!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glancing up, shocked) Oh my God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Halina! Henryk!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We heard you were here...we...didn't want...we...we wanted to be with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes his head, almost to himself, a forlorn smile) Stupid, stupid!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why did I do it? Why did I do it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why did I do it? Why did I do it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's getting on my nerves. What did she do, for God's sake?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly, to Halina) She smothered her baby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They'd prepared a hiding place and so, of course, they went there. But the baby cried just as the police came. She smothered the cries with her hands. The baby died. A policeman heard the death rattle. He found where they were hiding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you reading?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE MERCHANT OF VENICE BY WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE

dialogue.raw_text: (a crooked, ironic smile) 'If you prick us, do we not bleed? If you tickle us, do we not laugh? If you poison us, do we not die? And if you wrong us, shall we not revenge?'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very appropriate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking the book back and resuming his reading) Yes, that's why I brought it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Idiot. What's he think he's going to do with the money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much for a caramel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty zlotys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? For one caramel? What d'you think you're going to do with the money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty zlotys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning to the family) Have we got twenty between us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The locomotive pulling cattle and goods trucks comes into sight, rolling slowly towards the boundary of the Umschlagplatz and coming to a halt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A cordon of Jewish policeman and SS guards. Among the great throng of people, the Szpilmans trudge towards the train. Szpilman and Halina walking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Halina?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Funny time to say this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: wish I knew you better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a smile) Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : The Szpilmans near the train. The first trucks are already full, the people inside pressed close together, SS men pushing them with their rifle butts. People in the trucks cry out in desperation. The Szpilmans are pushed along by SS men along the cordon of Jewish policemen, past loaded trucks. Then, suddenly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A Jewish policeman grabs Szpilman by his collar and pulls him back out of the police cordon. It's Heller. The rest of the family have reached the next truck to be filled. A scuffle as Szpilman tries to resist. Another Jewish policeman shoves him. Szpilman stumbles, falls to the ground, in front of him the closed ranks of the Jewish policemen's backs. He stands, runs at the cordon, seeing between their heads, shoulders, Mother, Regina, Henryk and Halina clambering into the trucks. Father is looking around, bewildered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father sees him, takes a step towards him, but stops, smiling helplessly. He raises his hand and waves, then turns and goes towards the trucks. Again, Szpilman flings himself at the policemen's shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heller turns on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman stands for a moment, confused, terrified. Then he turns and starts to run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman drops to walking pace, makes for the gates. Workers are pushing carts piled with the bloated corpses that lay against the wall. Szpilman falls in with them and they pass through the gates.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Szpilman! Szpilman!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (yelling) Papa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (desperate) Papa! Mama! Halina!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think you're doing, Szpilman? I've saved your life! Now, go on, save yourself!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't run!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The doors of the trucks are closed. The train begins to move. Slow, laborious. From the trucks, the faint cries of the occupants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman catches his breath by a building. An SS man and Jewish policeman emerge. The Jewish policeman is servile, crawling to the German. He points to the train -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They laugh as they walk away. Szpilman turns and stumbles down the empty street. The cries from the trucks fading. He begins to weep, loud, agonised sobs, and staggers on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, off they go for meltdown!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman, lost, empty, aimless, tries to catch his breath in the aftermath of his tears. He wanders forlornly down the street, passing empty buildings with their doors open, windows smashed. Furniture, torn mattresses and pillows lie scattered. Feathers fly. Desolation. He turns a corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman comes into the courtyard. He stops, his face blank. Lying outside the door, the bodies of Jehuda, Mrs. Zyskind, their two sons and the toddler.  Szpilman steps across the bodies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chaos. Papers, pamphlets strewn all over the place. The mimeograph smashed. Szpilman enters, stands, surveying the devastation. Distant sounds of shooting, shouts, cries. He gathers up some papers in a pile, takes off his jacket and covers the pile of papers, making a pillow. He lies down on the floor. He stares into the darkness, expressionless, empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman shuffles along, comes to the cafe. No sign of life, but the door is wide open. He goes inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A shambles. Szpilman wanders through the upturned tables, broken chairs. Stops, looks about. Nothing. Distant shots, automatic fire. He turns and makes for the door. Then he hears an urgent hiss. He turns sharply and tries to find the source of it. He hears the hiss again. Now he sees, hiding under the platform, Benek, beckoning to him. Szpilman hurries over and crawls on his back until he's beside him. Benek replaces a plank and they are hidden from view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thin slivers of light illuminate the two men on their backs in the cramped space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't continue. Benek nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at him, mystified) Why are you here, Mr. Wladek?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's like this... I...we...all of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps they're lucky. The quicker the better. (Brief pause.) It isn't over yet. We'll stay here for a couple of days. Until things die down. (Another pause) I've bribed a policeman. He'll come when it's over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In bright sun, Szpilman and Benek march in a column, four abreast, under the command of two Jewish foremen, guarded by two German policemen. They are being marched out of the ghetto gates.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Benek) My God. I haven't been outside for - it must be two years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on the other side of him) Don't get over-excited.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Street traders with baskets full of wares, fruit, vegetables, fish, tins of preserves. Women bargain with them, making purchases. Lively, colourful. Dealers in gold and currency calling monotonously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later: Szpilman, on top of a free-standing scaffold, Benek and the others demolishing a ghetto wall, wielding skdgehammers. They work slowly. A smartly dressed young couple are passing, but stop. They stare. The young woman is extremely attractive and knows it. The foremen, workers and the German policemen ogle her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her young man is puzzled; she points.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Embarrassed, she giggles and they go. Szpilman, Benek and the others continue to work. The foremen sit, sunning themselves, and the German policemen stand, deep in conversation, ignoring the workers. Szpilman suddenly stops work. He has seen something in the square that alerts him. At the furthest stall, he sees a woman, attractive, chic, in her thirties, buying vegetables at a stall.  Her name is JANINA GODLEWSKA. Surreptitiously, Szpilman raises a hand, trying to catch her attention. But he's frightened of alerting the German policemen and the foremen. Benek has noticed.
