direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again Szpilman tries, but Janina, her profile to him, doesn't see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes back to work. The German policemen wander over to one of the stalls to buy fruit. The moment they do so two Jewish workers scamper across to another stall to buy bread. Szpilman glances across the square: Janina is still at the stall. He comes to a decision. He jumps down, is about to dash towards Janina, but stops dead. Janina is no longer there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gold, buy gold! Dollars! Roubles!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look - oh, do look!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jews!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't be the first time you've ever seen Jews.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someone you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A beauty. Who is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A singer. Her husband's an actor. I knew them well. Good people. I'd like to talk to her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (playful) Don't forget, Mr. Wladek, they hang them for helping Jews.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As before, Szpilman and Benek march towards the ghetto gates in the demolition column, four abreast, under the command of the Jewish foremen and guarded by the two German policemen. Suddenly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The column halts before a young SS man, wild-eyed, with his sleeves rolled up and wielding a pistol. He talks excitedly to the policemen then turns, walks along the column dividing them up: some men to the right, others, seven of them, to the left. Benek he orders to the left, Szpilman to the right. Young SS man turns to those on the left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terrified, they obey. He stands over them and, one by one, shoots them. When he comes to Benek, the seventh man, his pistol runs out of ammunition. He changes the clip, shoots Benek and marches off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Halt!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lie down!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman, bent almost double, carries a hod on his back piled with bricks. He is mounting a wooden ramp that runs up beside scaffolding on a small building site where an extra floor is being added to a house. There are Polish workers, too, who don't, of course, wear armbands as the Jews do. There's a wooden hut serving as a store on the site. Halfway up the ramp, Szpilman hears someone whistle. He stops, turns to see, at the bottom of the ramp, Majorek, smiling and giving a discreet wave. Later: Szpilman and Majorek sip gruel out of mugs. They sit apart from the others who are also taking a break.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brief silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whistle blows. A little later: Szpilman again mounting the ramp with a hod full of bricks on his back. The noise of airplanes overhead.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How long have you been here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since last night. I was pleased to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're going to start the final resettlement now. We know what it means. We sent someone out. Zygmunt. A good man. His orders were to follow the trains out of Warsaw. He got to Sokolow. A local railwayman told him the tracks are divided, one branch leading to Treblinka. He said every day freight trains carrying people from Warsaw forked to Treblinka and returned empty. No transports of food are ever seen on that line. And civilians are forbidden to approach the Treblinka station. They're exterminating us. Won't take them long. We're sixty thousand left. Out of half a million. Mostly young people. And this time we're going to fight. We're in good shape. We're organised. We're prepared.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you need help...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A swarm of Russian bombers. Anti-aircraft fire. Puffs of exploding shells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The workers look up. So does Szpilman and, as he does so, the bricks slide off his hod, crashing to the ground below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An SS man, ZICK-ZACK (his nickname), with a whip, approaches Szpilman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman goes to him. Enraged, Zick-Zack grabs him by the hair and presses his head hard between his thighs and then beats him mercilessly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a dozen or so strokes, Szpilman falls forward and lies in the dirt. Zick-Zack nods, satisfied.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two Poles, without armbands, one of them Bartczak, drag him away. Bartczak and the other man help Szpilman to his feet.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with every stroke, hissing through clenched teeth) Und-zick! Und-zack! Und-zick! Und- zack!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get him away from here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hope you played the piano better than you carry bricks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He won't last long if he goes on like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see if I can get him something better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Winter. Rain. Cold. The store, a wooden hut, contains wood, nails, tools, paint, metal brackets. Szpilman sits at a table, where a line of workers has formed. Szpilman makes a record in a ledger of the tools each worker takes out on the site. A worker puts his head into the store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Jewish workers start to assemble on the site in haphazard ranks as an SS Captain strides in. The SS Captain, with much jollity and jokes, hops up on to scaffolding and stands, beaming broadly, surveying the workers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A glance between Szpilman and Majorek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He beams; no reaction from the workers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rubs thumb and forefinger and leers; still no reaction; his smile vanishes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (hissing) Trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Assemble! Fall in! Only the Jews! Poles go on working! Only the Jews! Poles go on working!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in English) I have important and good news for you. There are rumours circulating that resettlement measures are again going to be taken.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in English) I want to assure you personally that no such measures will be taken now or in the future. Posters will be going up also to this effect. As proof of our good will, we want you to select a delegate, who will be permitted to go into town once a day to buy, on each worker's behalf, five kilos of potatoes and one loaf of bread, which you will be allowed to take back into the ghetto. Now, why would we do that j if we meant to resettle you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in English) You can do good business on what you don't eat. Isn't that what you Jews are best at? Making 'geld'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in English) Carry on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Snow. Majorek pulls a barrow by a rope attached to its shaft across the site. On the barrow, five sacks. The Jewish workers are phased to see him. Majorek pulls the barrow to where Szpilman waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman nods and starts unloading the sacks as Majorek moves away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (under his breath) The smaller one. At the bottom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman has unpacked the sacks and laid them in the corner. He kneels before the smallest of the sacks and unties the string around its neck. He puts his hand inside the sack and potatoes tumble out. He reaches to the bottom and is still as his hand finds something. Carefully, he removes a pistol, then another, both wrapped in oil cloths. He hides them under his jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman and a Jewish worker distribute the potatoes to the other Jewish workers lined up with empty containers of various kinds. There are scales on the table, and they weigh out five kilos of potatoes, pour them into the men's containers and drop in a loaf of bread.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Jewish workers, all carrying their parcels of potatoes and bread, march back towards the ghetto gates escorted by two Polish policemen. Szpilman walks beside them. Ahead of him, Majorek near the front of the column. As the column nears the ghetto gates, Majorek tosses his package over the wall and when Szpilman reaches the same spot, he throws a similar package. The column marches on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small room with several three-tiered bunk beds. The sound of men's heavy breathing and snoring. Szpilman lies awake, staring at the ceiling. He reaches inside his jacket, finds a scrap of paper and a pencil, writes something. He slips off his bunk and crosses to another set of bunks, crouches down at the bottom one, where Majorek sleeps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Majorek is instantly awake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Majorek takes the paper but says nothing. He turns over and goes back to sleep. Szpilman returns to his bunk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (whispered) Majorek!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have a favour to ask. I want to get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's easy to get out, it's how you survive on the other side that's hard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. But last summer, I worked for a day in Zelazna Brama Square. I saw someone I knew. A singer. Her husband's an actor. They're old friends. ( (He holds out the " piece of paper.) I've written their names down. And their address. If they're still there. Janina Godlewska and Andrzej Bogucki. Good people. Majorek, you go into the town every day. Would you try and make contact? Ask them if they'd help me get out of here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman has unloaded the sacks of potatoes into the corner and is kneeling, about to untie the string on the smallest sack. A sound alerts him. He looks round. An SS Lieutenant has entered the stores, sucking his finger, which is bleeding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman immediately hurries to a cupboard, finds a First Aid tin, removes a plaster and gives it to the SS Lieutenant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing from Szpilman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He indicates the sacks with his chin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The SS Lieutenant walks over to the sacks and kicks the smallest one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman tries to untie the string, but he's too terrified and can't manage it. The SS Lieutenant shoves him out of the way, then takes from his belt a dagger and cuts the string. The SS Lieutenant reaches in and withdraws a handful of long yellow beans. He glowers at Szpilman, reaches in again, produces a handful of oatmeal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He throws the oatmeal in Szpilman's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He kicks Szpilman viciously and marches away. Szpilman catches his breath, then quickly reaches into the bottom of the sack and finds a pistol and ammunition. He hides them under his clothes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Any fucking plaster?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (while he applies the plaster to his finger) What were you up to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the fuck are those?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in German) We're allowed to take food into the ghetto. Five kilos of potatoes and a...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Open it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's only potatoes and bread.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck that, you're lying, I can smell it. Open it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're all the same. Give a Jew a little finger, he takes the whole hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You lie to me again and I'll shoot you personally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Freezing cold. The Jewish workers, with their bundles of potatoes and bread, march back towards the ghetto gates escorted by the two Polish policemen. In the column, Szpilman, near the policeman with the moustache, and a little behind them, Majorek. Distant sounds of gunfire. Majorek falls in beside Szpilman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sudden, frantic cries from the head of the column, which comes to a stop. Two SS men, blind drunk, drinking vodka from bottles, are lashing the column with whips. One of them is Zikk-Zack, .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the SS men advance on Szpilman and Majorek's section, Majorek slips back to his place in the column. Szpilman hides his package inside his coat. Zick-Zack lashes out at the workers blindly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a swig of vodka and comes face to face with Szpilman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is staring directly at Szpilman with glassy eyes. Szpilman is terrified, trying as surreptitiously as possible to cover his hidden package with his hands. A moment of danger. Zick-Zack grabs Szpilman by the cottar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response; shaking him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and his comrade find this hilarious; recovering from his laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The column starts to march. ....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A brief silence, then from the back, a solo voice starts to sing, 'Children of Warsaw will go to fight!' Szpilman glances back, sees that it's Majorek singing. Szpilman smiles, Majorek nods. Szpilman joins in. Now, so do the others. They march on, singing lustily. ALL WORKERS (singing) Hey, ranks unite And follow the White Eagle! Stand up and fight Our mortal enemy. Riflemen, hey! Let's give them fire and brimstone. We'll blow away The yoke of slavery. Punish and rout The rapists of our nation. We'll smash the knout To save our dignity. Soon we'll be proud Of our liberation - Hey, take your sights! Aim sharply at the heart. Hey, load! Hey, shoot! Hey, load! Hey, shoot! Give 'em a bloody start! Hey, load! Hey, shoot! Aim sharply at the heart. The column reaches the lamp posts near the ghetto gates. Szpilman his package over the wall. So does Majorek.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I tried your friends. They're not at that address any more.  But.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You made contact? MAJOREK Be ready to leave in two days' time. Same place as last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, shit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Und-zick! Und-zack!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting") I'll soon teach you discipline! Jew pigs!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Know why we beat you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Know why we beat you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tentatively, in German) No. Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To celebrate New Year's Eve!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, march! Go on, march!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And sing! (he belches.) Sing something cheerful! (laughs.) And sing it good and loud!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Jewish workers lined up to get their potatoes and bread. Szpilman and two others weigh the potatoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Calmly, Szpilman leaves the table with the scales, walks past Majorek and the others, who, having got their potatoes, are assembling in a column, preparing to march back into the ghetto. The Polish workers have packed up their tools and are talking among themselves, also about to leave the site but in a casual way. The SS guards shout orders for the Jewish column to move off. Szpilman seems as if he's going to join them, but at the last moment turns and falls in with the Polish workers, beside Barczak, who just glances at him then moves so that Szpilman is in the middle of the group. Szpilman slips off his armband, stuffs it into his pocket. The group walk into the darkness.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get on with it and fall in! Fall in!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dimly lit. Empty street. Szpilman walks fast to the corner, stops, looks round anxiously. Nothing. He takes the armband from his pocket and drops it through the grating of a drain in the gutter just as there's movement in a darkened doorway. Szpilman tenses. Then, out of the darkness of the doorway, a woman: JANINA GODLEWSKA. She turns and starts to walk quickly. Szpilman, putting the collar of his coat up, follows, keeping pace. A pedestrian walks past in the opposite direction but pays them no attention. Janina and Szpilman walk on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Janina comes to the front door, opens it with a key, goes in. Szpilman, a little distance behind, catches up and follows her inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Janina waits as Szpilman closes the front door, then starts up the stairs. Szpilman follows. She stops, turns to him, smiles, kisses him on the cheek, then continues up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

location: HALL, STAIRS AND 3RD FLOOR, BOGUCKI BUILDING
result.heading: INT.

direction.raw_text: a handsome man, fortyish, tries to conceal his sense of shock at seeing Szpilman He holds out his hand and Szpilman shakes it. Szpilman looks around the nicely furnished, large apartment. He looks at Bogucki and Janina. Tears well up in his eyes. He fights it hard, not to cry. So does Janina.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We haven't much time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman lies in a steaming bath, eyes closed, as though he's in a trance. A gentle knock on the door and Bogucki slips in with some clothes. He gazes at Szpilman, whose eyes remain closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bogucki holds up a towel. Szpilman lifts himself out of the bath and dries himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You must hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're going to have to keep moving you. The Germans are hunting down indiscriminately now. Jews, non- Jews, anybody, everybody. (handing him the clothes') See if these fit. And, Wladek, you'd better shave. Use my razor. In the cabinet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The ceramic stove. Szpilman's ghetto clothes, torn into strips, are being stuffed into it and burned. Janina shoves the strips of clothes into the stove. Szpilman, now wearing Bogucki's suit and clean-shaven, watches the clothes burn while he spoons hot soup into his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Janina adds the last strip of clothing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll be looked after by Mr Gebczynski. He's on the other side of town. You'll stay there tonight. Then we'll find you somewhere else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll bring you food.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A rickshaw carrying Szpilman and Bogucki travels along the dark streets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rickshaw comes to a halt outside a store. The moment it stops the shutters of the store are raised and Bogucki escorts Szpilman to the door, then quickly returns to the rickshaw, which moves off fast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: shakes hands with Szpilman, ushers him in and then pulls down the shutter. Gebczynski's store is for sanitary furnishings and supplies: lavatories, basins, baths, taps etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leads the way and as he goes he picks up a cushion from a chair and a blanket. Szpilman follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll show you where you're going to sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Gebczynski leads Szpilman down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Dark, shadowy. Shelves with taps, washers, pipes. Gebczynski leads the may to a particular set of shelves. He puts aside the cushion and blanket, then starts to push at the shelves. Szpilman, although puzzled, helps. Slowly, the shelves move to reveal a secret compartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He helps Szpilman into the compartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands over the cushion and the blanket to Szpilman; then, putting his back to the shelves and his feet against the wall, he pushes the shelves back into place so that Szpilman is now hidden.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's not going to be very comfortable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll have to stay here until tomorrow afternoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've got a flat for you. Near the ghetto wall. But it's safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the cramped space, Szpilman is not quite able to stretch full out. With difficulty, he puts the cushion behind his head, starts to cover himself with the blanket but stops, seeing something. In niches, neatly stacked: rifles, pistols, grenades, ammunition Szpilman stares, expressionless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman and Gebczynski wait with others at the stop as the tram trundles towards them and comes to a halt. As they board:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly, to Szpilman) Go as near to the front as possible, to the German section.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gebczynski and Szpilman apprehensive, push through the rear section, packed with Poles, seated and standing, until they reach a chain and a sign:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the German section, only three or four passengers. Some read newspapers, others stare into space or out of the windows, but never looking at the Poles. Szpilman tries to appear as inconspicuous as possible. The tram rumbles on its way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gebczynski and Szpilman come up the stairs to the landing and to a door. Gebczynski unlocks the door and they go in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A charmingly furnished bed-sitting room with a comfortable divan. Gebczynski leads the way in. Szpilman glances around, goes to the window, looks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : He can see a section of ghetto wall below. Beyond it, inside the ghetto, a narrow street leading to deserted buildings. Gebczynski comes up behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leads Szpilman to the small kitchen. Gebczynski opens a cupboard to reveal potatoes, bread.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He closes the cupboard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Must feel better this side of the wall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but sometimes I'm still not sure which side of the wall I'm on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll come again. And Janina Bogucki will visit twice a week. Bring more food. See how you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Gebczynski makes for the front door, stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands over a scrap of paper, shakes Szpilman's hand and goes quickly. Alone, Szpilman stands, lost for a moment. Then, he takes off his shoe and stuffs the scrap of paper into it. While he does so, his eyes light on the divan bed. He goes to it, slips off his other shoe and lies down, testing the divan's springiness with his whole body. He smiles beatifically. He shuts his eyes and is instantly asleep.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, now, this is very important. In case of emergency, I mean emergency, go to this address.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman still fast asleep. Voices wake him. He opens his eyes. He's not certain where he is for a moment. He hears the voices again, coming from the adjoining flat. Intrigued, he rises, goes closer to the watt, puts his ear against it, listens. After a brief silence:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.  Szpilman is enjoying himself. Then the sound of a piano being played with great feeling but a lot of wrong notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The piano continues for a moment, but suddenly stops:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A door slams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.  Szpilman smiles but then hears the sound of rifle shots and a huge explosion. He crosses quickly to the window, looks out. SZPILMAN'S POV - THE GHETTO. Deserted. Stillness. Silence. From the ghetto smoke drifting slowly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (angry) Puppydog, what d'you mean, you forgot?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What d'you think I mean, Kitten? I forgot, that's what I mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what? You treat me like dirt!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I treat you like dirt because you are dirt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pig!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cow!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pig!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bitch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dirty pig!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a dirty pig!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Takes one to know one! Pig!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You play like an angel, Kitten.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I play like an angel, why don't you listen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was listening, Kitten.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Liar, you fell asleep. Pig!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wheedling) Kitten, let me in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman asleep on the divan. The roar of motor car and motorcycle engines. Sporadic firing. He wakes, rushes to the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : A German personnel carrier, an open car carrying officers, and a motorcycle and sidecar roar down the narrow street below towards the buildings at the far end. German soldiers follow behind on the trot, pulling a field gun. Unseen marksmen fire down on the Germans from the buildings. As the German soldiers dismount from their vehicles one of them is hit and falls. The others rush for cover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MINUTES LATER - EARLY MORNING The German Commander and two officers alight from the car and take cover. The Commander orders the field gun to be trained on the buildings. Spasmodic firing continues. He gives the order to fire. The gun roars. The shell tears into the building. At once the German soldiers open fire with their rifles and lob grenades into the building. The gun fires again. The building begins to burn. Flames and smoke. German soldiers with flame-throwers advance carefully then unleash their fire into doorways and windows, and quickly retreat. At ground level, Jewish fighters try to fight their way out and are mowed down. The fire spreads quickly through the building. Smoke begins to pour from the upper floors. The Germans, less cautious now, stand and watch. A woman struggles out on to her narrow third-floor balcony. She climbs over, holds on to the wrought-iron railings and hangs on for dear life. Shots ring out and she drops like a stone. From inside the building, screams and shouts. From another upper window, a man in flames jumps and falls to his death on the pavement below. The Germans have stopped firing. They stand, spectators, watching the building burn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY Szpilman at the window, watching, his mood downcast. The noise of a key in the door. He turns to see the door of the flat open. Janina enters with a parcel of food. She kisses Szpilman on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands him the parcel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes into the small kitchen and unpacks the contents while Janina gazes out of the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: she turns to look again out of the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: wanted to come earlier but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one thought they'd hold out so long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: should never have come out. I should've stayed there, fought with them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning to him) Wladek, stop that. It's over now. Just be proud it happened. My God, did they put up a fight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, so did the Germans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're in shock. They didn't expect it. Nobody expected it. Jews fighting back? Who'd have thought?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but what good did it do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (passionate) What good? Wladek, I'm surprised at you. They died with  dignity, that's what good it did. And you know something else?  Now the Poles will rise. We're ready. We'll fight, too. You'll see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The building burning. Corpses lie scattered on the pavement. The Germans stand about chatting and laughing. A handful of Jewish fighters are lined up and shot. Satisfied, the Commander returns to his car. Another officer confers with him before the engine starts up and he is driven away. The building burns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 1ST APARTMENT, SZPILMAN'S POV - DAY Blazing sun. The ghetto buildings now burned-out shells, the street empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Autumn leaves falling and gusting in the wind. Szpilman gazes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snow. Ice on the windows. The sound of the key in the door. Szpilman turns as the door opens and Gebczynski enters, distraught. Whispered, at speed:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gebczynski takes out a cigarette and lights it. While he does so:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he goes. Szpilman listens to his footsteps clattering down the stairs. He sees the cigarette stub, takes it, lights it, coughs, smokes awkwardly. Later: Szpilman hears a car engine and the screech of brakes. He tenses. German voices shouting and their heavy footsteps on the stairs. He goes to the window, opens it. He gets a chair, places it sideways in front of the window to make a step. He's working out how best to throw himself out. He leans against the wall near the door and waits.. Slamming of doors, German shouts, a scream. Szpilman steels himself, ready to jump. Again footsteps on the stairs, but this time descending. A door slams. He cautiously goes to the window and looks out. INT./EXT. 1ST APARTMENT - DAY SZPILMAN'S POV - THE STREET. In the street below, he sees SS men escorting two prisoners and shoving into a car. The car speeds off. The street is empty.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get your things together, you have to leave!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm on the run!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Gestapo found our weapons. They've arrested Janina and Andrzej. They're bound to find out about this place, too - you must get away at once.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where do you want me to go?  Look at me. No, no, I'm not leaving. Can't I take my chances here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's your decision. (Stubs out cigarette.) But when they storm the flat, throw yourself out of die window - don't let them get you alive. I have poison on me, they won't get me alive either!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Snow. Howling wind. Szpilman lies on the divan. He is cold, unshaven, hair filthy and long. He manages to rise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A mess. Szpilman goes into the kitchen. From a bread tin he takes a small, flat greaseproof paper parcel and unwraps it. A slice of bread, stale and mouldy. He tries to bite it but can't. He finds a knife and tries to chop a piece off the bread but knocks the bread tin, which falls to the floor with a clatter. He continues to try to cut the bread, when there's a loud hammering on the front door. Szpilman stiffens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The hammering continues as Szpilman stumbles into the room, looks around, confused, not knowing what to do. From the other side of the door female voices, words indistinct, and then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is galvanised into action, puts on a crumpled jacket, grabs his tattered coat and scarf, collects up a few of his things, stuffs them into a paper bag. The hammering stops. Szpilman cautiously approaches the door, listens, then opens it quietly and slips out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Open this door at once, or we'll call the police!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He slips out of the flat, goes to the stairs and stops dead. KITTY, young and fierce, stands on the stairs, blocking his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman hesitates; she shouts more loudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On various floors, doors open, tenants put their heads out to see what's going on. Summoning all his strength, Szpilman makes a dash for it, pushing past Kitty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman clatters down the stairs, reaches the ground-floor landing. Another woman tries to bar his way but he pushes past her and out of the house.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you from the flat in there? You're not registered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It belongs to a friend of mine. I came to visit but I must have just missed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting) Have you got your identity card? Let me see your identity card!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to see your identity card!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (screeching) He's a Jew! He's a Jew! Stop the Jew! Don't let him out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Heavy snow. Szpilman stumbles into the street and runs. He darts down a side street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman lurches into the narrow street. No one about. He stops, almost collapses, but manages to keep hold of himself. He puts on his coat and wraps the scarf round his neck. He leans up against a wall. He removes a shoe and takes out the scrap of paper Gebczynski gave him. He reads it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman drags himself along, trudging through snow and slush. Passers-by give him a wide berth. He tries to walk normally, with dignity, but he's weak and slips, and finds the going hard. He comes to a villa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes to the front door, rings the bell and waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens and Dorota stands there. She is pregnant. They stand for a moment staring at each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (from behind the door) Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr Gebczynski sent me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a whisper) Wladyslaw Szpilman. SZPILMAN Dorota. DOROTA Come in! come in!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman follows Dorota into the living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman sits down slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Awkward silence. He gazes at her. She looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods. Brief silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again, the awkward silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens and Michal Dzikiewicz enters. He sees Szpilman and stops. Szpilman stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shakes hands with Szpilman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman, dizzy, leans on the table for support.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and Dorota look at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry - I was given this address. I'm looking for a Mr-- (He checks the scrap of paper.')
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: a Mr Dzikiewicz.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) Michal Dzikiewicz. He's my husband.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need help. DOROTA He'll be back before curfew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been in hiding. I need somewhere to stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'll be here soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long have you been married?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just over a year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And how's Yurek?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When's your baby due?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Christmas. (A pause.) This is not a good time to have children. But then...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is my husband. Wladyslaw Szpilman. Marek Gebczynski sent him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes. I remember.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr Gebczynski said to contact you only in an emergency, but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry now. We can't move you tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll sleep on the sofa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, could I have a piece of bread?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course, we'll eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman asleep on the sofa. The sound of a cello. He opens his eyes. Listens. He swings his legs off the sofa, stands, and crosses to a door. Quietly, he opens it a little. Szpilman and his POV - another room. Dorota, partially turned away from him, plays Bach on the cello. Szpilman watches her and listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A padlock being unlocked. Then, a key is inserted into the Yale lock, turned, and the door opens. Michal and Szpilman on the landing, enter the flat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A large room, sparsely furnished but with an upright piano and a bed. Michal carries a bag of provisions and puts them on a table while Szpilman goes immediately to the window and looks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : There are views of the city, but in the street below, opposite, is a hospital and, on the corner, a building flying a Nazi flag and guarded by a sentry, standing at his sentry-box. Michal comes up behind Szpilman.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in whisper) You're in a very German area. The building opposite is a hospital, taking in wounded from the Russian front. Next door is the Schutzpolizei. It's the safest place to be. Right in the centre of the lion's den.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Michal makes for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods and goes. The sound of the padlock closing. Szpilman takes in the room. He sees the piano, is still for a moment, then goes to it. He sits on the piano stool and adjusts its height. He opens the lid. A cloth covers the keys. He removes the cloth. He gazes lovingly at the keyboard. He flexes his fingers. Then, without touching the keys, his fingers floating just above them, he plays. Silently. Passionately.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be locking you in. No one knows you're here. So keep as quiet as possible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . POINT OF VIEW THROUGH WINDOW - DAY Snow falling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman alert, hearing the padlock being unlocked and then iheYdle. The door opens and Michal enters, accompanied by a man, aged about thirty, Szalas, confident, a little brash. In whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szalas and Szpilman shake hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szalas produces a quarter bottle of vodka, thumps the back of the bottle so that the cork flies out. He finds glasses and pours. While he does all this:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives the others their vodka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They clink glasses and drink.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is Antek Szalas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's going to look after you. I've given him a second key. He'll bring you food. See that you're all right. He's with the underground, a good man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't remember me, Mr. Szpilman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't think so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Warsaw Radio. I was a technician. I saw you almost every day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, I don't remember.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doesn't matter. You've nothing to worry about. I'll visit often.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you'll be pleased to hear the Allies are bombing Germany night after night - Cologne, Hamburg, Berlin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the Russians are really giving them hell. It's the beginning of the end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's hope so. I don't know when I'll see you again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Summer. Trees in leaf. Comings and goings at the Schutzpolizei building. And an ambulance draws up at the hospital, disgorging a couple of stretcher cases, who are carried inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: very weak and his skin yellowish, drops four beans into boiling water. The Sound of the padlock being opened. Szpilman hurries to see the door open and Szalas enter with a small and grinning cheerfully. In whispers: SZALAS Still alive then, are you? Here. Sausage. Bread. He hands over the package. You still got that vodka? Szpilman stares at the package.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szalas shrugs, finds the vodka, pours two glasses
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He unwraps the package to reveal sausage and bread. He takes a bite of sausage, chewing deliberately, slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szalas goes to the window, looks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman thinks for a moment, then takes off his wristwatch, hands it to Szalas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szalas pockets the watch, makes for the door, stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grins, downs Szpilman's vodka, gives a mock salute and goes.  Hie padlock is locked on the other side. Szpilman enjoys his sausage.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How long is this meant to last?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: think I've got jaundice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't want to worry about that. My grandfather was jilted by his girl friend when he got jaundice. (chuckles.) In my opinion, jaundice is not very serious. Drink up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you come sooner? It's been over two weeks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Problems. Money. I've got to raise money to buy the food. I need things to sell, it' s not easy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sell this. Food's more important than time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes. I meant to tell you. The Allies have landed in France. The Russians'll be here soon. They'll beat the shit out of the Germans. Any day now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sunshine floods in through the windows. Szpilman lies inert on the bed, weak, starving, ill. The sound of the padlock. He doesn't stir. Dorota, no longer pregnant, and Michal enter, come to the bed. In whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman barely has strength to open his eyes and focus on them. He mutters incoherently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leaves. The padlock sound. Dorota goes to the kitchen, wets a towel, comes back to the bed, kneels it, places the towel on Szpilman's brow. He focuses on her, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman suddenly winces with pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him; barely audible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later: Szpilman looks up at Dr Luczak, who has a stethoscope in his ears. Dorota and Michal stand behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Doctor and Michal leave his line of vision. Dorota moves in beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman tries again to say something, but he can't, just lies there, distressed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wladek? Wladek! (to Michal) I knew it, I knew this would happen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to get a doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't, it's too dangerous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll get Dr Luczak, we can trust him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dorota, don't be ridiculous, he's a pediatrician.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's still a doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you stay, I'll go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We came to say goodbye. We're going to stay with my mother in Otwock.The baby's already there. It's safer. There's talk that the uprising will begin any day now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That man Szalas should be shot. He's been collecting money on your behalf all over Warsaw. Apparently, people gave generously. So he collected a tidy sum. He told us he was visiting you daily.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Acute inflammation of the gall bladder. Liver the size of a football. But he'll live. I'll try to get hold of some levulose, but it's not easy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you visit him again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who knows?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doctor, thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't speak. Rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Michal brought food. I'll prepare something now for you, then we must go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman looking down from the fourth-floor window. Peaceful. A few pedestrians. An everyday atmosphere. At the far end, at the T-junction with a main road, a tram rumbles down the street and comes to a halt, disgorging passengers on the far side and so out of sight. The tram continues on its way, now revealing the few passengers who alighted '97 women, an old man with a stick. Last, three young Poles, carrying long objects wrapped in newspaper. One of the men looks at his watch, glances around, then suddenly kneels and puts the package he's carrying to his shoulder. The sound of rapid firing, which makes the newspaper at the end of the packet glow to reveal the barrel of a machine gun. His two companions have also put their packages to their shoulders and begin shooting, all aiming their fire at the Schutzpolizei building. The sentry is hit and falls in front of his box. As if these young men have given a signal, now from all over the city comes the sound of gunfire. The pedestrians have scattered except for the old man, gasping for breath, hobbling on his walking stick, who eventually manages to disappear inside a building. Rifle and machine-gun fire from the Schutzpolizei building. The firing intense. The three young Poles manoeuvre to the corner opposite the Schutzpolizei and toss grenades into the building. EXT. DOWN IN THE STREET - DAY A battle raging. The Germans firing from the hospital. The three young Poles have been joined by other fighters and they the Schutzpolizei building. Grenades thrown, machine-gun fire exchanged. The sentry box blows up, splinters of wood cascading. A couple of Poles make a dash for it and enter a building opposite to the Schutzpolizei.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman watching from his window, looks in the opposite direction and sees smoke rising. When he turns back to look towards the T-junction, he sees a Panzerfaust anti-tank rocket firer poking out from a window in the next-door building but on the floor below. The Panzerfaust fires. The shell hits the hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The city in flames. Sound of firing becoming sporadic, less intense. Isolated explosions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman, lying on the bed, staring at the ceiling. EXT. 2ND APARTMENT - SZPILMAN'S POV - DAY The interior of the Schutzpolizei building burnt to cinders. An ambulance is being loaded with patients from the hospital. A horse-drawn cab rounds a corner and clatters down the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman at the window, watching. The horse-drawn cab clatters out of his sight. He is about to draw back when he sees, directly beneath him, a man and woman walking with their hands in the air. Then, a German soldier, pointing his rifle at their backs, appears. Suddenly, the man and woman begin to run. The man turns and disappears. The woman also turns, but the German soldier drops to one knee and fires. The woman clutches her stomach, drops slowly to her knees and collapses on the street in an awkward kneeling position, and that's how she remains. Szpilman watches, aghast. Then, he hears voices outside his door, shouts, footsteps, panic. THE APARTMENT: He runs to his front door and listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More clatter of footsteps. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Footsteps descending stairs, more shouts, and:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman runs to the door, tries it but it's padlocked and he can't open the door. In panic, he runs back to the window. His eyes grow wide with terror. SZPILMAN'S POV: AGAIN THE STREET. A German tank bringing its gun to bear on the building next to his. The gun jerks back and there's a great roaring noise. The whole building shakes. Szpilman reek back, falls, gets to his feet and crawls back to the window. He sees the tank turret swivelling slowly, bringing the gun to bear directly on a lower floor of his building. The roaring noise again. A terrific explosion. His windows are shattered. Glass everywhere. He is thrown back across the room. Smoke begins to billow and fill the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (confused) Where? Where? Just get out! Everywhere! Get out into the street!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get out now! The Germans have surrounded the building! They're going to blow us to pieces.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (further off) Everyone out, please! Leave your flats at once, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Smoke filling the room. Szpilman gets to his knees, peers through the smoke and sees that the wall separating his apartment from the one next door has been partially destroyed, with a large hole blasted in it. He stumbles into the next-door apartment and out of the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smoke everywhere. Szpilman staggers up to the fifth-floor landing. There's a metal attic door. Szpilman pushes open the door and steps into the attic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The roof space with laundry drying on lines. Szpilman enters the attic, closes the door, leans on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks round, sees that the roof has been shattered, leaving a large, jagged gap. He climbs through the gap, on to the roof at the back of the building.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Fourth floor, Fischke!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The attic door being kicked in by a German boot. A German soldier, wearing his gas mask, bayonet fixed, enters the attic, looks round, sees nothing, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The soldier turns and hurries out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: At the double, Fischke!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On the sloping roof, Szpilman clutches the skylight and has his feet in the roof gutter. He listens - all quiet in the house. And then a bullet ricochets off the tiles beside him. Szpilman, terrified, drops, involuntarily catching a lower edge so that his feet dangle above a balcony below. More shots. He drops on to the balcony and looks back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two German soldiers are firing at Szpilman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman clambers back into the building through the smashed balcony door. A couple of shots dangerously close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smoke. Szpilman staggers down the stairs, stumbles over a corpse and almost falls headlong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sun is setting. Szpilman crawls into the backyard. He hears German voices shouting commands. He hides behind three garbage bins by the wall. He waits. Listens.  Silence
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Deserted. Buildings on fire but dying out. Corpses in the street, including the woman who was shot, still in her strange kneeling position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman watches from the doorway. Then, dropping down, he crawls across the road on his stomach, threading his way through the dead bodies, now besieged by flies, and makes for the hospital opposite. German soldiers appear from around a corner. Szpilman immediately lies still, pretending to be just another corpse. Flies alight on him. When the Germans pass, he sets off again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dark.  Szpilman crawls into a corner, rests. He's exhausted. He tries to take stock of his surroundings. He can make out the operating table. He manages to drag himself on to it. He lies there, his eyes grow heavy. He sleeps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: German soldiers dragging the corpses into a pile. A sergeant douses the bodies in petrol, then sets them alight. The bodies burn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From a shattered window on the first floor, he looks at the burning bodies. Two German soldiers wander into his eyeline. He draws back a little but watches them warily. They sit just beneath him, chatting, and take out their food-tins, drink coffee and eat bread.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman wanders down the passage, sees into the wards, the empty beds, the broken furniture and medical equipment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman opens cupboards, drawers, searching, but trying to be as quiet as possible. He sees the refrigerator, quickly gets to it, pulls open the door. Empty. He looks around and notices a red fire bucket with a spade and a box of sand next to it. The bucket is full of water, covered with an iridescent film and full of dead flies. He drinks as much water as he can without swallowing the flies and, while he's doing so, he spots a couple of sacks. He opens the first: potatoes. The second contains barley. He tries to eat the uncooked barley but can't. Later: A fire on the floor. Szpilman holds a saucepan over it and is cooking the barley and some potatoes. He manages to scoop out a spoonful, blows to cool it, then eats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman at a window sees autumn leaves thick on the ground. And at the end of the street, a line of Poles, some with their hands in the air, others with hands on heads, being marched away by German soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RUINED HOSPITAL - DAY. Szpilman lies in bed under several layers of blankets. Ice on the windows. He hears German voices shouting commands. He sits up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ./EXT. RUINED HOSPITAL, SZPILMAN'S POV - DAY Szpilman gets to a window and looks out. German soldiers with flame-throwers are burning the buildings opposite. One soldier, with a bucket of white paint and a brush, numbers the building. Szpilman cranes to see them reach the end of the street, then cross over and start on the buildings on his side, working their way towards the hospital. He pulls away and makes for the back of the hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman goes to a window, jumps out. He twists his ankle. He's in pain. He crawls across the back garden and climbs over the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Devastation, not a human being in sight. Nothing. Emptiness. He is alone. Szpilman hobbles away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cautiously, Szpilman limps towards the villa, a once grand building, but now partly damaged by shell fire. He makes his way in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman enters the hall, still showing signs of its former opulence. I Silent. Ominous. He looks round anxiously, then sees the stairs leading down to the basement. He hurries towards them and descends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dark, shadowy. Szpilman comes down a flight of wooden stairs that had directly into the kitchen. Immediately, he begins to search fractically, opening cupboards, drawers. He finds a can with a label illustrating pickled cucumbers. Desperately, he searches for something to open it with. He discovers a pair of scales with a variety of weights. He seizes one of the weights when, very close, he hears the sound of a car coming to a halt, then the car door slam, a German voice giving commands. He drops the weight but, holding the tin, he scampers up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman, clutching the unopened tin, makes his way up the narrow, wooden staircase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman, panting heavily, reaches the top floor. He sees a small door, tries it. It opens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman enters, closing the small door behind him. He leans back, resting, recovering. And then he hears from down below a piano playing a Beethoven piece. After a few bars, the music stops. Szpilman listens anxiously. Silence. He looks around, finding himself in an attic space filled with junk, a ladder, rotting material, travelling trunks. Last light of day filtering through a dormer window. There's a ladder leading up to a trapdoor. Szpilman climbs the ladder. He crawls into a small empty space. With enormous effort he pulls up the ladder and closes the trapdoor. Exhausted and trying to catch his breath, he gazes at the unopened tin. He peers through the darkness but sees nothing. His eyes begin to droop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Artillery fire. Fires glow on the horizon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman wakes suddenly. He listens. Silence but for the distant gunfire. He sees the unopened tin of pickles, stares at it. He opens the trapdoor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman, a shadow, a spectre, creeps down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman has placed the tin and the weight on a shelf and is engrossed in searching again. He finds a pair of chicken scissors. Using the weight, he starts to hammer the point of the scissors into the tin making a perforation round the rim. The tin slips off the shelf and rolls across the floor coming to rest at a pair of highly polished jackboots. Szpilman stifles a gasp. On the stairs, in silhouette, gazing down at him, the figure of a GERMAN CAPTAIN, the thumb of one hand caught in his belt above his pistol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman just stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He studies Szpilman for a moment, then with a nod orders him to follow. Szpilman picks up the tin and follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (stern) Who the hell are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (barely audible, in German) I was... I was trying to open this tin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where do you live?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's your work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am... I was a pianist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A pianist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman follows the German Captain through a double door, hanging off its hinges, into a room with a broken table in the centre, what once was the dining room. And then through another set of doors. The German Captain's boots echo. They come into a spacious room. Faint moonlight filters through the large windows. Fallen masonry and broken glass. A couple of chairs. And a grand piano in the corner. The German Captain points at the piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman hesitates, then limps to the piano, puts down the tin, and opens the lid. He turns and drags one of the chairs over and sits. The German Captain stands and watches. Szpilman glances surreptitiously at his hands, and then he plays Chopin. The German Captain listens, expressionless. The pale moonlight shows him to be a handsome, elegant man. Szpilman finishes playing. Silence. Somewhere, a cat mews. Distant burst of rifle fire. The German Captain stares at Szpilman. After a moment:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long pause. Szpilman just stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman hesitates, takes the tin and then shuffles past the German Captain towards the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Play.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you hiding here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jew?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you hiding?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in German) In the attic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman and the German Captain enter. The German Captain takes out a flashlight, sees the ladder in place, leading up to the loft. Szpilman climbs the ladder, squeezes into the loft and looks down at the German Captain, who shines his light on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman shows him the tin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes quickly, leaving Szpilman in darkness. Szpilman, overcome by relief, can barely catch his breath.
direction.name: direction

location: ATTIC AND LOFT AREA, RUINED VILLA
result.heading: INT.

dialogue.raw_text: Have you anything to eat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll bring you something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The German Captain strides out of the villa, down the front steps to a waiting car and a driver. He gets into the car. The driver starts the engine and the car speeds off into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman hears the car's engine growing fainter. He starts to tremble and then begins to cry. He weeps uncontrollably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Much activity: officers coming and going, orderlies typing. Officers king on field telephones. Desks, filing cabinets. The German Captain, carrying a bulging shoulder bag, marches into a room just off the hall and goes to his desk just as an orderly drops papers in his in-tray. On the desk, there's a framed photograph of him nth a woman and two children. German Captain glances at the papers, takes a pen, initials one or two and then goes. THE GRAND STAIRCASE: The German Captain marches up the stairs purposefully, as if he's on urgent business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The German Captain enters. He puts two fingers in his mouth and whistles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a moment, the trapdoor shifts and Szpilman looks down. The German Captain takes a package from his shoulder bag and throws it up into the loft. He turns to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The German Captain stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes quickly. Szpilman opens the package, finds bread and marmalade. Then he finds a tin-opener.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Open up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's all that gunfire?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Russians. On the other side of the river. (Turns to leave, stops; with a touch of irony:) All you have to do is hang on for a few more weeks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Snow. The sound of distant gunfire. The Germans are evacuating the villa. Men carry out boxes, filing cabinets, desks, papers and load them into trucks. They're careless, leaving a trail of debris. No sentries now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman, listening and shivering with cold. He hears the whistle. He opens the trapdoor to see the German Captain in the attic, carrying a package.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman descends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman faces the German Captain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands Szpilman the package. Szpilman opens it to find inside several loaves of bread.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. Szpilman shivers with cold. The German Captain takes off his coat and gives it to him.
direction.name: direction

location: ATTIC AND LOFT AREA, RUINED VILLA
result.heading: INT.

dialogue.raw_text: Come down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's happening?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're getting out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in German) Are the Russians here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know how to thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't thank me. Thank God. It's His will that we should survive. Well. That's what we have to believe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got another one.  Warmer. (brief pause) What will you do when it's all over?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll play the piano again. On Polish radio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me your name. I'll listen out for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Szpilman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Szpilman. (a crooked smile) Good name for a pianist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Freezing weather. Empty streets. Then the sound of recorded music, as a car, with a loudspeaker and a Polish national flag, comes into view, the Polish national anthem blaring out from the speaker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman, wearing the German Captain's coat and under the eiderdown, hears the strange sound of the music, which he recognises. He's astonished, puzzled. He comes to a decision and starts to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cautiously, in his German military overcoat, Szpilman trots down the staircase into the empty hall. He goes to the front door, opens it a crack and cautiously goes out. EXT. STREET - DAY Szpilman looks around, hearing the car loudspeaker indistinctly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His excitement grows and he walks out into the street. He sees at one end soldiers serving soup from afield kitchen to a group of people. On the opposite side of the street, he sees a man and a woman who have left the field kitchen. The man carries a two-tiered canister. Szpilman rushes towards them, grabs hold of the man and tries to kiss him. The man, totally bewildered, tries to fight him off. The woman is terrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She runs, yelling, towards the field kitchen. So does the man. Szpilman stands and stares, then sees one of the soldiers cock his rifle and fire at him. Szpilman runs, the firing continuing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...German army! Polish soil liberated!  Official!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: German! German!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman bolts into the doorway of a ruined building. He peers out to see Polish soldiers beginning to surround the ruined building, firing shots, lobbing in a grenade or two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More shots and another grenade explosion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Polish soldiers: Two of the officers stand near the entrance, hearing Szpilman's shouts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Polish officers confer briefly in whispers. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And they march him off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting) Stop, for God's sake, I beg you, I'm Polish!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't shoot! I'm Polish!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's Polish!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (yelling) Come out with your hands up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (obeying) Don't shoot! I'm Polish! Please, please! I'm Polish!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, he's Polish!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as Szpilman approaches') Why the fucking coat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm cold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take him to headquarters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Spring. Idyllic. A column of men and women stretching along the length of the lane. A couple of horse-and-carts. One or two bicycles. Some of the people wear concentration camp garb, others in tattered clothing. Four men walk together and when they come to a narrow junction, stop, seeing something Behind barbed wire, German prisoners of war, guarded by Russian soldiers. Desolate place. No shelters, no tents. The POWs sit or lie on the ground, silent, broken, shattered. The four men gaze at them. :
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fourth man, ZYGMUNT LEDNICKI, approaches the barbed wire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands glowering at them, then sees a POW rise from a group, wretched, shabby, unshaven. It's the German Captain, uniform tattered, a wreck. He comes to the barbed wire.
direction.name: direction

location: LONG COUNTRY LANE AND HOLDING CAMP
result.heading: EXT.

dialogue.raw_text: Look at them - bastards!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: German fuckers!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I prayed for this, never thought I'd see it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Murderers! Assassins!  Look at you now! You took everything I had! Me, a musician! (wagging his finger fiercely) You took my violin! You took my soul!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (urgent) (in German) Do you happen to know another musician, a Mr Szpilman? A pianist! Polish radio?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course, I know Szpilman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (desperate) I helped Mr Szpilman when he was in hiding. Tell him I'm here. Ask him to help me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: inside the compound, approaches, grabs hold of the German Captain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drags the German Captain away from the wire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The German Captain is being bundled away by the guard, who aims a kick at him. The German Captain shouts out his name but it's unintelligible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The German Captain and the guard have disappeared. Lednicki stands for a moment, then turns and goes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Lednicki, in Russian) Hey! No talking to the prisoners. Get away from there!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as he backs away, calling) What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Szpilman playing the piano. He looks something like his former self, fairly well dressed and groomed. He glances towards the glass booth and sees Lednicki with the technicians. He smiles. Lednicki nods, smiles back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Szpilman and Lednicki looking around an empty field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lednicki goes. Szpilman stands, looking around the empty field. He is filled with sadness. He sits. He closes his eyes and put his face to the sun.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It was here, I'm certain of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not here now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I shouted abuse at them, I'm not proud of it, but that's what I did, and, I'm certain, I stood where you are now. There was barbed wire, and this German came up to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't catch his name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I'll ask at the factory. They may know something.
